title: Rare Egyptian Protests See Dozens Arrested
text:
CAIRO—Egyptian authorities made dozens of arrests after hundreds of people took to the streets of Cairo and other cities overnight in the first significant antigovernment protests in years, raising a new challenge to the rule of President Abdel Fattah Al Sisi.

Crowds of protesters faced off with police in riot gear late Friday and into Saturday morning near Cairo’s Tahrir Square, the center of the Arab Spring protests in 2011 that ended the 30-year rule of President Hosni Mubarak. The demonstrations appeared to be set off by videos circulating online alleging government corruption. Protests also took place in Alexandria, Suez, Damietta.

Though small compared with those during the Arab Spring, the protests were significant because they defied a vast government effort overseen by Mr. Sisi to stamp out political dissent since he took power after a military coup in 2013.

Unauthorized street protests are now illegal in Egypt. Security forces killed more than 1,000 people and arrested tens of thousands of others in the aftermath of the 2013 coup, meaning that any demonstrations come with high personal risk for those demonstrating.

The protesters in Cairo chanted “Leave!” and “The people demand the fall of the regime!” Police fired tear gas to disperse one group of protesters.

At least 56 people were arrested, according to the Egyptian Center for Economic and Social Rights, a human-rights group that released a list of names of those detained.

The unrest followed new allegations of corruption against Mr. Sisi that have created a storm of online criticism of his government.

A man who identified himself as a former government contractor called for the protests, accusing Mr. Sisi of graft in a series of online videos posted from self-imposed exile in Spain to his Facebook page. Mohamed Ali, who also works as an actor, accused Mr. Sisi of building lavish palaces for himself and wasting public funds on projects like a luxury hotel near Cairo.

Protesters shout slogans during a rare anti-government protest in Cairo in the early hours of Saturday. Photo: Oliver Weiken/Zuma Press

The previously little-known Mr. Ali, 45 years old, said he was owed millions of Egyptian pounds for various projects, including residences for Mr. Sisi. The claims in the videos and Mr. Ali’s identity couldn’t be independently verified.

Mr. Sisi denied wrongdoing and dismissed Mr. Ali’s accusations as untrue in a speech at a hastily-organized conference last week. “I swear to God, these are lies and slander,” he said.

But the videos generated a renewed debate around allegations of corruption in Egypt’s military-dominated economy, which includes billions spent on megaprojects like a new administrative capital under construction in the desert outside Cairo. According to Twitter, more than a million tweets appeared on the site this week calling for the removal of Mr. Sisi and supporting the call for protests.

“We have wealth that could feed 100 million Egyptians and more but your president does not know how to manage it,” said Mr. Ali in one video. Mr. Ali couldn’t be reached immediately for comment.

Earlier this year, a majority of Egyptian voters approved constitutional changes that would allow President Abdel Fattah Al Sisi to remain in power until 2030, following a referendum in which people campaigning against the changes were arrested.

The opposition has said the outcome of the vote was undermined by the government’s use of state institutions to ensure passage of the changes. Voters said they were offered cash and food to participate in the referendum.

In one video, Mr. Ali urged Egyptians to take to the streets and called on Egypt’s defense minister Mohamed Zaki to arrest Mr. Sisi.

Hundreds heeded Mr. Ali’s call, descending to the streets of major cities following a nationally televised soccer match.

Egyptian officials made no public statements in response to the protests. Earlier on Friday, Mr. Sisi flew to New York where he is set to attend the annual gathering of world leaders at the United Nations General Assembly.

The Egyptian protests emerged as new democratic movements gather strength across North Africa after demonstrations forced out the longtime autocratic leaders of Sudan and Algeria earlier this year.

Living standards have dropped for most Egyptians in recent years as Mr. Sisi’s government devalued Egypt’s currency and raised the price of basic goods and services like fuel, electricity, and subway tickets.

The changes are part of austerity called for under a $12 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund agreed upon in 2016. The economy is growing at a rate of 5.4% but poverty is also on the rise, with 32.5% of Egyptians now living in what the government describes as extreme poverty, up from 27.8% in 2015.

Mr. Sisi’s government has also expanded the role of the military and other security services in the economy, putting pressure on the private sector and generating resentment from ordinary Egyptians who see themselves as left out of any growth in the economy.

Write to Jared Malsin at jared.malsin@wsj.com
description: Egyptian authorities made dozens of arrests after hundreds of people took to the streets of Cairo and other cities overnight in the first significant antigovernment protests in years.
